text: Two wrinkled, aged hands work the udder of a COW. Milk spurts down into an old METAL PAIL.

It's time to go. REVEAL: an OLD WOMAN, stocky, babushka, sitting on a smal wooden stool. She continues to milk the cow. Her cloudy eyes gaze straight ahead at her task. The job has done a thousand times. The SOLDIER, 27, tall, strong, stubbly face, sweating in uniform, stands a few feet behind her. They're in a weed-filled front yard. A dilapidated wooden fence, paint faded and peeling, slumps and weaves around small property. In the near background, a tiny home. Logs and concrete. A rippled tin roof. At least as old as its owner. The soldier wipes his brow. Then waves a cloud of gnats away. Frustrated.
Did you hear me? She keeps milking.
This is an evacuation. You understand? You have to come with me. She does not stop milking. But:
Why?
Why? Because they told me, so now I'm telling you. Everyone in this village. Everyone. It's not safe here. There's radiation in the air. What's wrong with you?
Do you know how old I am? The soldier slumps. Hot. Sweaty. This is miserable.
I don't know. Old.
I am 82. I have lived here my whole life. Right here. That house. This place. What do I care about safe?
I have a job. Don't cause trouble.
Trouble. Tschh. You are not the first soldier to stand here with a gun. When I was 12, the revolution came. Oh, for god's sake...

Czar's men. Then Bolsheviks. Boys like you marching in lines. They told us to leave. No. Then there was Stalin, and his famine. The Holodomor. My parents died. Two of my sisters died. They told the rest of us to leave. No. The soldier softens a bit. Doesn't want to be disrespectf

Then the Great War. German boys. Russian boys. More soldiers. More famine. More bodies. My brothers never came home. But I stayed. And I am still here. After all that I've seen. So I should leave now-- because of something I cannot see at all? No. The pail is full. She stops milking. The soldier takes a couple of steps forward. Reaches down gently to take the pail. She doesn't move to stop him. He lifts it up, walks a few steps, and then SPILLS THE MI OUT on to the ground-- --where it SPLASHES into a puddle right next to a SIMILAR PUDDLE... a dark-and-white milky spot on the ground.  She doesn't turn to look at him. Just waits. Fine. He walks back to her. Hands her the pail. She takes it, places it under the cow's udder. A small si And then she begins milking again. SOUND: a TRUCK HORN. The soldier turns and looks out to T DIRT ROAD, where a military bus is WAITING. Yeah. He know Just a minute. The soldier looks back at her. Resolute now. All business

Please stand up now. She does not. Nor does she speak. The only sound is the s moo of the cow. The milk hitting the bottom of the pail. The soldier puts his hand on his holster. THE OLD WOMAN - hears the SNAP of a button as the soldier unholsters his weapon. But she doesn't move. Keeps milkin The soldier draws his Makarov. Chambers a round. cha-chik

This is your last warning. She keeps milking. The soldier purses his lips. Sweat rolling down from his forehead. Then he takes aim. CLOSE ON THE OLD WOMAN - tired eyes. Ready. Her hands kee milking. Like they always have. All these years. All this
She blinks. THE COW - topples to the ground with a heavy thud. Milk still leaking from its udder. The old woman just stares at it. White rivulets dribbling out into the soil. Then they stop.
It's time to go. cuT TO TITLES  403 404 405 406
A bloc of IDENTICAL APARTMENT BUILDINGS. In the center courtyard, a small PLAYGROUND. Some young mothers stand together, smoking, watching their children play.

An empty apartment. Lyudmilla enters the frame from behin REVERSE TO - C.U. LYUDMILLA - looking at the empty space. This is where she will live now. This is her home. She looks back at the BUILDING CONCIERGE, a woman in her 50's, who stands waiting by the door. Lyudmilla nods. Yes WIDER SHOT - Lyudmilla stands in the empty space. We see that her belly has grown. About five months pregnant now. The concierge leaves, and now Lyudmilla is alone. Her hand absent-mindedly goes to her stomach. No. Not alone.
Point five. Point seven. Point five.

location: AN OPEN FIELD NEAR A POND

text: CLOSE ON: A GAS MASK-covered face. It stares dead ahead. the dark lenses of the goggles, the distorted reflection men... moving slowly in a pack through early morning FOG. THE SURVEY TEAM - thirty soldiers, each wearing plasticky green radiation suits, hoods pulled tight over their head Their masks make them look like strange, nightmarish bird  407 408 They move in a fanned-out formation holding RADIOMETERS i front of them, like astronauts exploring a distant planet THE TEAM LEADER - holds a map in his hand. He makes notations as they call their numbers out.
Point three. Point seven. Point six. From off-camera:

Fifteen. The soldiers stop dead. All turn as one. The lack of expression on the masked faces somehow makes it worse. REVEAL: a soldier holding his radiometer out toward a tre A child's RUSTY BICYCLE leans against it. Someone rode he to swim in the pond, and left the bike behind because of flat tire. The soldier turns back. Repeats.

Fifteen. The team springs into action. Half the soldiers rush over the hotspot. Using their radiometers to find the perimete The others grab supplies from the truck. They work in perfect coordination to erect fencing around the hotspot. A final sign planted in the ground. A yellow triangle. Cyrillic lettering. But we won't need a translation. The red RADIATION SYMBOL on the sign is enough. The sound of approaching HELICOPTER BLADES, and the Team Leader looks up, his masked face staring at the sky.

Where we first met them... the night of the explosion. Th apartment is mostly as we saw it then. Lyudmilla's cigare in the ASHTRAY, stubbed out a lifetime ago.  409 410 411 But there is plaster dust covering the table where she sa And rat droppings. The calendar is frozen, and will forev be, on April 1986.
CLOSE ON: LEGASOV - by the window. Lost in thought. Smoki Anxious. PHONE: rings, jarring Legasov back to reality. He picks i up.
Legasov. (checks his watch) Alright. I'll be there to meet him. He stubs his cigarette out in the ashtray, and:

A military car heads down the long road toward-- DRIVER'S POV - the approaching CHERNOBYL POWER PLANT The car pulls into the reactor site area and comes to a stop. GENERAL TARAKANOV emerges. He stops to take it all A grim pause. Then he strides toward the MOBILE OFFICE.

CLOSE ON AN BLACK AND WHITE AERIAL PHOTO of CHERNOBYL. Th massive, gaping wound in Building 4. Wreckage still cover the roof of the building. Tarakanov sits at the table with Legasov and Shcherbina. Just staring at the photo. Then he flips to the next. And the next. Images of utter destruction.
The atom is a humbling thing.
Not humbling. (drops the photos) Humiliating. Why is the core still exposed to the air? Why haven't we already covered it?

We want to. But we can't get close enough. The debris on the roof is graphite from the core itself. Until we push it off the roof and back down into the reactor, it will kill anyone who goes near it. As he speaks, he pulls photos to show Tarakanov.

You can see the roof has three levels. We've named the sections-- that small one there is Katya. About a thousand roentgen per hour. Presume two hours of exposure is fatal. (points again) The one on the side-- Nina. Two thousand roentgen. One hour, fatal. Tarakanov shakes his head. Hard to believe such a thing could be true. Rocks. Rubble. A building.
We used remote-controlled bulldozers in Afghanistan. Maybe--
Too heavy. They'd fall right through.
So then-- ?
Moon rovers. Tarakanov looks at Legasov. I'm sorry, moon rovers?
Lunokhod STR-1's. They're light, and if we line them with lead, they can withstand the radiation.
We couldn't put a man on the moon, at least we can keep a man off a roof.
That is the most important thing, General. Under no circumstances can men go up there. Robots only. Taraknov looks back at the photo.
What about this large section? Legasov and Shcherbina fall silent. Then:
Masha. Tarakanov picks up the tone in the older man's voice. Reverence. Or is it dread?

Twelve thousand roentgen. If you stood there in full protective gear, head to toe-- you would receive a lifetime dose in ninety seconds. At two minutes, your life expectancy is cut in half. By three minutes-- you're dead within months. Tarakanov looks down at the photo of MASHA. Graphite chun enlarged in the photo as blurred, ominous shadows...

Even the lunar rovers won't work on Masha. That amount of gamma radiation penetrates everything. The particles literally shred the circuits in microchips apart. If it's more complicated than a light switch, Masha will destroy it.
I think it's fair to say this piece of roof is the most dangerous place on the planet.
(stunned) So... what do we do?
That's what we were going to ask you.
In the far distance, a small LINE OF BUSES is barely visible, moving toward us.  413 414 415

Men. All men. 20's and 30's. Two in each seat. No expressions. Hard faces. Most have the look of men who ha seen war. Except for: PAVEL, 23, the thin boy we saw at the end of the last episode. He sits in a window seat, nervous. Crowded sligh by the huge man next to him. PAVEL'S POV - through the window, nothing but open countr And then, as the bus slows... MILITARY VEHICLES. A checkpoint. Two soldiers in gas masks. As the soldiers wave the bus through, Pavel sees a third soldier on his hands and knees, vomiting on the ground. Pavel quickly looks away from the window. Stares straight ahead. Afraid.

The buses are parked in a field. The men stream out. Pave exits, clutching his conscript papers in his hand. Ahead of him - TENTS. Scores of them. Makeshift shelters, large enough to house eight men each. As Pavel follows al with the others toward a check-in point, we see: COOKS - stir enormous vats of god-knows-what over field stoves. SUPPLY MEN unload crates from trucks and stack th on the ground. Each crate holds the same thing. VODKA. Hundreds of crates. Thousands of bottles. In the background, a row of men squatting over a trench latrine. Other men throw garbage into a fire pit.

Pavel carries a pile of folded UNIFORM CLOTHING, two boot and a cap. A small BLACK AND WHITE PIECE OF PLASTIC - lik rectangular badge - is now clipped to his shirt. He's checking the numbers posted on the tents. 101... 102  416 10.

Pavel pushes through the flap and enters the small tent. Inside, we see it's the kind you'd set up on a battlefiel for temporary quarters. In fact, the exact kind. Except for the empty vodka bottles scattered around. Most the cots are empty, but messy, as if their occupants have already left to do their jobs. But there is one man... sitting on his cot, cleaning a RIFLE. This is GARO, 30, Armenian, thin. The same PLASTIC BADGE clipped to his shi Garo turns to Pavel, and we see: his right eye is CLOUDED OVER. Dead. A small scar winds around the socket.

I was sent here? Tent 103? Another MAN, face down on a COT, groans. Turns over, wake up. Disoriented. As he sits up, an empty bottle rolls off his cot, and hits the ground with a dull thunk. This is BACHO, 36. Tall, muscular. Pants but no shirt. Hi entire body-- his posture, his build, the way he juts his head-- appears to be designed to commit violence. He squints at Pavel through bleary eyes.
New?
Yes. Bacho rises... all 6'1" of him. Picks up a nearly-finishe vodka bottle and a METAL CUP. Walks with a slight sway to Pavel. Offers the bottle.
It's okay. It's free.
It's a little early. Bacho shrugs. Yes, that's true. He holds out his hand. Pa shakes with him, wincing a bit as the big man squeezes hi hand.
Bacho.
Pavel.  417 Garo nods. 11. Bacho picks up a shirt. Also a PLASTIC BADGE on it. He pu it on while he talks.
So what unit were you in?
They had me in the motor pool in Kiev, but--
No no, not this bullshit. Afghanistan. What unit?
I wasn't in Afghanistan. I'm not in the military. Bacho takes that in. Wooooow. He turns to Garo.
They're running out of men. Yup. Bacho wipes his nose. Then SLAPS his own cheeks with his Takes a huge breath. Shakes the cobwebs out. Then claps Pavel on the arm. Hard enough to leave a bruise.
Alright. Let's go. Bacho exits the tent. Pavel just stands there. Then sees Garo staring grimly at him with his one good eye.
Pavel rushes to catch up with Bacho, who starts pointing things out to him as they go.

Showers. Food. Those guys over there? They dig up the ground. Those guys, they cut down trees. Those guys I think evacuate people, you know? Like villagers? Pavel gestures toward a different group of men.
What about them?  12.

I don't know them. Fuck them. (sees, yells) Janek, you Latvian whore! JANEK, 25, picks through a PILE OF STUFF... boots, caps, cups, pots, pans. He looks up and sees Bacho walking at h with purpose. Shit. That's not good.
I'm not Latvian, I'm Estonian.
Well guess what, no one gives a shit. Give me an egg basket.
I only have one, I promised it to-- Bacho juts his face toward Janek. Fist cocked.
Give me the fucking basket.

Okay, okay...! Janek pulls a CURVED PIECE OF FLAT GRAY METAL from the pi It has four small holes punched into it, with shoelaces running through them. Like... a metal loincloth? Bacho snatches it out of Janek's hand. Then makes a motio to smash Janek in the head with it. Janek FLINCHES back. Then Bacho points to Pavel. Eyes still glaring at Janek.

He's with me, you understand? Nobody messes with him. Janek raises his hands up... doesn't want trouble. Bacho, still scowling, gives a satisfied grunt. Then he turns to Pavel-- instantly calm again-- and hands him the bent met
We make these from lead scrap. Put it on under your balls. His balls? Pavel looks at the metal. Then realizes that Bacho is staring at him. As in... waiting.
Now?  13.
No, you should wait until the radiation gives you a cunt. Yes now. Pavel looks around. Okay. He drops his trousers.
Over your clothes. Holy shit. Embarrassed, Pavel pulls his trousers back up. While he p his egg basket on, Bacho continues to smoke. And talk.
You ever go hunting?
No.
Well, today's your lucky day. You, me, that one-eyed Armenian in the tent? Garo? We do animal control.
Animal control? Bacho makes a gun gesture with his hand.

They're radioactive, so that's that with them. And the best part? It's mostly pets. They're happy to see you, they run right up to you! Bang! Load the bodies on a truck, dump them in a pit, bury them in concrete... and then we drink. Pavel finishes tying the egg basket on.
As much vodka as you want, plus a thousand rubles. It's almost worth it, you know? Without warning, he SLAPS his hand hard against Pavel's crotch. Right in the egg basket. Pavel flinches in pain.
Good. Let's go get you a gun. Bacho strides off, and once again, Pavel follows.  418 419 420 421 14.
The foreboding building, with its jutting central tower covered in bone-white tile, looks more like a prison fortress than a repository of knowledge.

Khomyuk waits by a check-in desk in front of a security gate. A SECURITY OFFICER - male, 30's, has her credential in front of him on his desk. He painstakingly records her information into a LOGBOOK. sound but the scratching of his pen, a tunk-tunk-tunk of unseen clock, and the hum of overhead lights. Finally, he hands her credentials back, then hits a butto There's a BUZZ, and the security gate clicks open.

A large, two-level reading room. Long wooden tables run t length of it. KHOMYUK sits alone at the end of one of the tables. Stacks of books. Journals. Maps. Notepads. And a THICK BINDER with page after page of a dot matrix printout... an infodump from a computer, no doubt. We catch bits of her work as she progresses. Mathematical calculations. Notations referring to time of day. Marked- diagrams of a nuclear reactor. Photographs of control roo instrumentation... panel schematics... She circles A3-5 (AZ-5 in Cyrillic) on a schematic. Leans back. Thinks. Then checks one of her books. No. Wha she's looking for won't be in there. She tears a blank pa from her notepad and starts writing.

An elderly male librarian sits behind an open window... a bit like a bank teller. Behind him, a few desks and walls card catalogs. The secure reference section. He looks up from his work. Sees Khomyuk waiting.
Yes?  422 15. She hands him the piece of note paper through the window.
I need to see the following documents. They're listed as permission only. He takes the paper... and then a LETTER she hands him.

I'm working for the Central Committee. He puts on his glasses. But before he can even read the letter, a MAN IN A SUIT, 40 comes into view behind him. The KGB agent takes the list from the old man, who meekly looks down without protest. He walks back to a desk. Pick up a phone. Dials. While he mutters to someone on the phone, Khomyuk waits quietly. The old librarian still keeps his eyes down. Doesn't want to know her. Doesn't want trouble. THE AGENT - has a BLACK PENCIL in his hand. Whoever he's called is giving him instructions. He swipes the pencil across her list. Once... twice... three times... Khomyuk holds her anger in. The agent finally hangs up. Walks back to the librarian. Puts the piece of paper down Every single request has been CROSSED OUT except for one.
She can have that one. The agent lifts his head to stare at Khomyuk. A challenge for her to argue. But all he gets back is:
Thank you, comrade. He gives a little smile. Oh well. Perhaps next time.

Over SCORE... no other sound... SLO-MO... dreamlike... BIRD'S EYE VIEW - an enormous, wide-open cabbage field. N ROWS of vegetables. Then: THREE BULLDOZERS - enter frame, moving in a line, perfect unison, destroying the harvest in rows just as neat.  423 424 425 426 427 428 16.
SCORE/SLO-MO continues: THREE CHOPPERS glide like mosquitoes over a small, abando village, each dumping FOUR EVEN STREAMS of BROWN DECONTAMINANT, which land on everything like paint.

SCORE/SLO-MO continues PUMP TRUCKS roll down the main street, each spraying an a of BROWN FOAM DECONTAMINANT to the side. MEN IN PROTECTIVE SUITS - hoods drawn tight, faces covere in GAS MASKS, walk in front of the procession of trucks, spraying the road in a waving motion with handheld-nozzle connected to TANKS strapped to their back. It almost seems celebratory. Some kind of sick parade...

A chunk of GRAPHITE. Scattered beyond it, more of the sam The bits of rock sitting on the scorched pitch-covered ro give the impression of an alien surface. And adding to that eerie sense... in the B.G., we see a FOUR-WHEELED VEHICLE - like a retrofuturistic go-cart, sitting on the roof. The LUNAR ROVER. It's about eight feet long. Steel piping Cameras mounted on articulated arms. The tires are paper thin, with barely-there hubs made of needle-like spokes. A BULLDOZER ARM AND BLADE have been welded onto its front  429 17.

A small, undamaged room under the roof. OPERATORS sit at a small table. Control equipment and sma square TELEVISION MONITORS are stacked. And a COMPUTER. O the walls, PHOTOS of the roof. A boxy CONTROL MODULE sits on the desk. Cables running in and out. Two switches. Two rows of LIGHTS. The lights are all currently RED. Legasov and Shcherbina watch, nervous, as Tarakanov waits with a walkie-talkie by his ear. Then:
We're clear. Tarakanov takes a breath. Then to his operators:

Bring up the cameras. The lead operator, JUGHASHVILI, hits the first switch on control module. THREE RED LIGHTS - turn GREEN. The other three remain red. THE MONITORS - flicker to life. Different IMAGES of the r from the rover's cameras. And ONE REMOTE SITE CAMERA show the LUNAR ROVER ITSELF.
Signal?
Acceptable. Running onboard diagnostics.
Tell me when we can start moving it. Shcherbina moves in closer to stare at the montior.
To think that's what they put on the moon...
Well, not that one.
(glares) I know not that one.  18. Legasov shrugs. Sorry.
This rover was in storage, and I'm told they can build two more. That should cover Katya and Nina.
And Masha?
The Central Committee has informed me they've found something that can work up there. From the outside.
American?
Of course not. No, it's a German police robot. West German, though. You can imagine that wasn't easy.
Diagnostics complete, ready to engage main power and motor. Legasov and Shcherbina get ready. If this doesn't work...
Begin. The operator turns the second switch on the control modul Nothing. The lights stay red. Everyone is dead quiet. The

Again. The operator goes back to the switch. Off. Then on. Still nothing. Red lights. The monitors continue to show the rover's view of the roo Slightly askew. The graphite chunks. The bits of fuel assembly. All at rest.
Again. Like a doctor refusing to acknowledge a patient is dead. Once more, the operator switches the power off. Then on. again, nothing. Red lights. Then... in rapid succession..  430 19. GREEN.

(my god) Can you move it? The operator grabs hold of his remote, and begins pushing the small joystick. ON THE MONITORS - a lag, then... IT MOVES. The operators react. Breathing. Laughing. On the screen, rover is moving along, starting to PUSH DEBRIS. Doing exactly what they had hoped. Shcherbina makes a fist in the air. Triumph. Then sees...

Valery? Is that...? Is that a smile? Legasov sheepishly waves him off. But yes. A smile. The first one we've seen on his face. Shcherbina puts his arm around Legasov. Hugs him close, laughing. Yes. YES! Hope.

Dyatlov sits in a chair. Smoking. Looking out the window. His hair appears to have come back a bit. A bit of moustache, though it wasn't what it was. The lesions have faded. But he does not look healthy. At all. Behind him, a knock on the door. He doesn't answer. We he the door opening, and:
I see your condition has improved. Dyatlov turns. Sees her there, back in her protective clothing. In her hand, a small manila folder. He waves her away in contempt.
No. Leave.
I need your help.  20. Dyatlov raises his arms slightly to the side to show her of the IV tubes running in and out of him. How is he supposed to help anyone? But:
Akimov initiated AZ-5. When you gave him the order, was--
Order? What order? Toptunov called it out, Akimov pressed it. That was the only good decision they made. Incompetent morons.
(ignores that) Can you confirm the reactor exploded after they attempted to shut it down? He gives her a strange smile.

How do I even know it exploded? Hmm? Out of patience, she opens her folder, pulls out a PHOTO, and SLAPS IT DOWN in front of him. It's an AERIAL VIEW of the EXPLODED REACTOR. And for a moment, Dyatlov is shaken. He pushes it away. Already doing whatever mental gymnastics are required to forget what he just saw. But Khomyuk knows he won't forget it. She takes the photo back, and hands him a JOURNAL ARTICLE from her folder.
I pulled this from the state archives, written in 1976. It's about the operation of RBMK reactors under extreme conditions. Dyatlov barely looks at it.
So?
The names of the authors have been redacted. And two pages have been removed.  21. Dyatlov hesitates. An old, habitual paranoia rises. Is sh testing him?
The State must protect its secrets, Comrade Khomyuk. Do you dare suggest otherwise?
(quieter) They made a mistake. They didn't redact the table of contents. He slowly flips to the first page. Sees it.
The missing pages apparently refer to a positive void coefficient and AZ-5. Does that mean anything to you?
(suspicious) What are you after here? Why are you asking me this?
You worked with this reactor. You know it better than I do--
So everything's my fault then? Is that what this is?

(snaps) I'm not here to blame you. I'm here to find out what happened. And whether you realize it or not, I am the best chance you have to avoid a bullet. Can you help me or not? Dyatlov stares at her. Then flips through the article to missing section. Scans around it briefly. Then, honestly:
I have no idea what would have gone here. Void coefficients have nothing to do with AZ-5. He tosses the article at her. Dismissive.
There. Now you can go.  22. She picks the article up from the floor. Then:
(disgusted) You're not even curious.
What for? You think the right question will get you the truth? There is no truth. Ask the bosses whatever you want. He stubs out his cigarette.
You will get the lie. (beat) And I will get the bullet.

A stakebed truck. Bacho drives. Garo sits next to the oth window. Pavel is squeezed in between. Bacho is peering at a MAP he has on the dashboard. It kee falling. Son of a bitch. He grabs it, then reaches across Pavel to Garo, who hands him a bottle of vodka. Bacho drinks and drives. Grabs the map again. Drinks agai The truck jostles on the uneven road.
Fucking thing. Pavel is nervous. Bacho offers him the bottle.
No. Thank you.

What, are you afraid we're going to run out? Trust me, we won't. It's the one thing we always have. In Afghanistan, when we needed guns, they sent vodka. We needed penicillin? They sent vodka. Boots, morphine, fuel? Never the right things. Never enough. Except the vodka. So you might as well drink. Bacho turns to Pavel. Not looking at the road at all.  Garo shrugs. 23.
I'm not asking. I'm telling. Because of the radiation. It protects you. (catches the map) Where the fuck are we? Garo? Takes the vodka bottle.
Do they tell you how much there is?
How much what there is?
Radiation. Bacho laughs. And Garo starts to chuckle along with him. Pavel isn't sure what that means.
I saw a man throwing up. On the side of the road.
Yeah, that happens. Pavel touches the white-and-black badge on his shirt. The one they all wear.
But we have these. To measure. So they know. (no response) The radiation we get.

That's right. They check them every day. You're allowed to get a total of 24 roentgen. If you hit 24, you get to go home. And if you go over 24, your commanding officer gets arrested for negligence. Maybe even shot. Does that make you feel better?
Yes. (beat) How much do you have?
Me? They tell me I have 23 roentgen. Go ahead, ask Garo how much he has.  432 433 24. Before Pavel can ask or Garo can answer--
He has 23. We all have 23. And we will never have more than 23. You understand now? Pavel falls silent. Yes. He does understand. Bacho points ahead.
Ay! There it is. Fuck this map. I told you I knew where I was.
The truck rumbles toward a SMALL VILLAGE - a few dozen buildings... one main street... all quiet. No one left.

The truck squeals to a stop. The three men get out, and w around to the back of the truck. Bacho pulls the back of stakebed down, and opens a LARGE METAL BOX. It's full of BULLETS. Hundreds? Thousands? They're bound clusters of five rounds each, held together by thin steel stripper clips. Bacho forks over a fistful of bullets to Pavel. Garo take three Mosin-Nagant rifles from the back of the truck. Bacho loads his rifle, then sees Pavel struggling. Wow. Bacho grabs the gun from Pavel. Shows him how to insert t stripper clip. Bullets go in, empty clip comes out. Slide the bolt to chamber.

Got it? Okay. Now listen. I only have two rules. One, don't point this gun at me. That's easy, right? (gestures to Garo) Point it at this piece of shit, I don't give a fuck. Never me. Two, if you hit an animal and they don't die, you keep shooting until they do. (gets in Pavel's face) Don't let them suffer-- or I'll kill you. Understand? I mean it. I've killed a lot of people.  434 25. Pavel glances at Garo, who gives a tiny nod. It's true. Bacho has killed a lot of people. Pavel looks back at Bacho. Yes. Understood.
(friendly pat) Then we're ready.
Eerily quiet. A few cars are where their owners left them Some clothing hangs on a line, swaying in the breeze. THE THREE MEN walk down the street. Rifles at the ready. Bacho turns to Pavel.

Watch. Bacho gives a WHISTLE. The kind you might give to a dog. And sure enough... there's a BARK. And another. And now, tentatively emerging from alleys and empty buildings... DOGS. And CATS. Hungry. But clearly domesticated. Tails wagging. Hopeful eyes. Bacho turns to Pavel.

When we start, they'll run where they feel safe. Always inside. So we go door to door, okay? Okay. And without warning, Bacho raises his rifle and FIRES. We hear a YELP, and he FIRES again. We don't see it. We just hear BARKING and HOWLING as Bach and Garo keep walking, right out of frame, FIRING. Gunsho Sliding bolts. Shells hitting the ground. Gunshots. PAVEL - stands in horror, blinking every time a GUNSHOT r through the air. He hasn't even raised his rifle. PAVEL'S POV - Bacho turns back to him. In the B.G., we se some scattered corpses of dogs.
Pavel snaps out of it.  435 26.
(points to an alley) Door to door. Do your job. Pavel nods, frightened, and moves toward the alley.

Pavel walks slowly down the alley. Forcing himself to breathe. Trying not to throw up. A SHEPHERD MUTT lifts its head from a pile of RUBBISH. Sniffs the air. Even in the bedlam, desperate to be fed. Pavel stops. Raises his rifle. Shaky hands. Finger on the trigger. But... can't. Lowers the gun. Then: the dog TURN TO HIM. And BARES its TEETH. Pavel backs up. The dog stalks forward. Starvation and ti have turned it feral. The dog growls, protecting its rubb pile, and what little food is in it. Snaps and barks. Pavel waves his rifle at it, as if the animal might understand.
Go! The dog keeps advancing. Faster. Pavel keeps backing up.

The dog BARKS... CHARGES, and: CLOSE ON PAVEL - panicked - he SHOOTS... We HEAR BUT DO NOT SEE - the dog YELP in pain and thud to the ground. And now the sound of rapid, wheezing breaths. We stay on Pavel, who moves closer to where the dog fell. Shock on his face. At what he did. Agonizing seconds tick by. A scared man. The sound of a dying animal. Heavy breathing. Pain. And then: BOOM. A bit of BLOOD spatters up into Pavel's face. No mo sound from the dog. BACHO - stands there. Angrily EJECTS the shell from his rifle, chambers another one, and then gets in Pavel's fac Nose to nose. Dead serious.  436 27.
Don't let them suffer.
I'm sorry. Bacho glares into Pavel's face-- then points down.
You're dragging that on the truck. Bacho marches off, and Pavel stands there, staring down i shock at the dead dog. In the background, steady gunfire.

THUNK. A vodka bottle is slammed down on a table. Now wed of cheese. Salami. A loaf of bread. Bacho and Garo sit at table outside an abandoned cafe. They use their knives to cut the loaf, stab at the meat and cheese. Big mouthfuls. Deep swigs of vodka. Bacho looks over at PAVEL - who sits apart. Shellshocked.
(mouth full) You going to eat or what? Pavel stares at the street. Streaks of blood and tracks i the dirt where the animals died... and were dragged away.

Hey. Pavel shakes his head. No. Bacho shrugs. Takes Pavel's fo adds it to his pile. Then realizes... Pavel is wiping at eyes. Fighting off tears. Ah, shit. Bacho and Garo share a glance. Garo nods at him "Do something." So Bacho pours vodka into Pavel's cup, wh shakes his head no.
(gentle, but firm) Drink. (he does) Again. Pavel takes another swig.  28.

Look... this happens to everyone their first time. Normally when they kill a man, but for you-- a dog. Eh, so what? There's no shame in it. This isn't going well. Pavel takes another drink. Wants t get numb. Bacho tries again.
Garo, you remember your first time? As per usual, he doesn't wait for an answer.

My first time-- Afghanistan-- we were moving through a house-- a man was suddenly there-- and I shot him in the stomach. That's a real war story. They're never good stories, like in movies. They're shit. Man is there, boom, stomach. (what can you do?) I was so scared, I didn't pull the trigger again for the rest of the day. I thought, well-- that's it, Bacho. You put a bullet in someone. You're not you anymore. You'll never be you again. But then you wake up the next morning, and... you're still you. And you realize-- that was you all along. You just didn't know. A long pause. Then:
The happiness of all mankind. The first words we've heard him speak.

What? Garo points across the street at: A PROPAGANDA BANNER - slung between two buildings over th main street. A picture of Lenin on one side, and a proud Soviet worker on the other. And in between, Cyrillic lettering.  437 438 439 29.
"Our goal is the happiness of all mankind." The three men stare at the absurd sign hanging over the blood-stained street in a dead town. Then Bacho gets up. Oddly chipper. No cracks in his dam.
I'm happy. I'm happy every day. He grabs his gun. Then:
Back to work. Bacho marches off. Pavel looks at his rifle. Then picks i up. Vodka in his veins. Takes a breath. Yes. Back to work. He gets up, and follows.
Seemingly empty, but for the debris. Less, though, than w saw before. And then: a LUNAR ROVER enters frame, PUSHING DEBRIS alon with its small bulldozer blade... moving toward the edge.
We're twenty feet below the roofline here, pointing strai up at the edge of Katya. The ROVER slowly appears, and pushes GRAPHITE off the edg It cascades down toward us...

WIDE - from this distance, we can see it all. The tiny rover. The falling graphite. The debris plummets from the roof and down into THE GAPIN CRATER where the reactor used to be. Then we swing around slowly to find the larger section of roof. MASHA - the deadliest place on Earth. Still covered debris. Still untouched.  440 441 30. Still waiting.

Multiple rover camera POVs are visible on the monitors. Jughashvili and the other operators drive them with their joysticks. There are more computers now. More control modules. All o the lights are green. Shcherbina watches them work. Behind him, Legasov sketche cleanup paths on the photos of the roof. They turn in unison TARAKANOV enters.
It's here.
Legasov and Shcherbina watch as Tarakanov organizes the offloading of the truck's sole cargo.
Careful now. Slow. SLOW. That's it. Soldiers gingerly offload an ORANGE, HIGH-TECH ROBOTIC VEHICLE with TANK TREADS. It's far more muscular than the flimsy lunar rovers.
(proudly) Joker. Legasov and Shcherbina turn to Tarakanov. What now?
That's what the Germans named it. "Joker."  442 443 444 31.
(heavy sigh) Germans. (beat) Is it ready?
It's ready. Shcherbina looks at Legasov. Legasov nods.
So. Let's introduce Joker to Masha.

CLOSE TO THE ROOF SURFACE - black chunks of graphite. One the pieces has the tell-tale smooth semicircle in it... t channel for a fuel rod... The wind picks up... granular bits of deadly graphite swi and - JOKER lands SOFTLY on the rubble. The cable coupling detaches, and the helicopter QUICKLY swerves away from the deadly roof. Joker sits there. Impressive. Armored. Strong. This is clearly a superior vehicle. A match for Masha.
Legasov, Shcherbina and Tarakanov stand behind the operators. Nervous anticipation.
Good signal.

Cameras. Jughashvili hits a switch on the control module. A GREEN LIGHT immediately comes on. ON THE MONITORS - views from Joker's cameras. Legasov and Shcherbina watch intently. So far, so good.  32.
Motors. Jughashvili hits more switches on the control module. The lights go GREEN in succession. Joker is the real deal.
Motor good, signal good.

All right. Let's start easy. Forward one metre, reverse one metre. The operator pushes a joystick. Legasov and Shcherbina st at the monitors. Unblinking. Please. ON THE MONITOR - the image SHIFTS... as Joker MOVES.
Forward one. The men in the room are all smiling.
(nudges Legasov) Germans!

Reverse one. He pulls back on the joystick, and on the monitor, we can tell Joker is faithfully moving backwards. Then: THE MONITORS lose signal. STATIC. CONTROL MODULE - the GREEN LIGHTS start to turn RED... on two, three.... then ALL of them. Dead silence in the room. No one breathes. Then:
Did you lose the signal? The operators are flipping switches. Checking the remote TRANSMITTER boxes. Sweating.
It's not the signal. It's the vehicle. He turns back to Tarakanov. Pale. At a total loss.  445 33.
It's dead. They all stand there in shock. All but for Shcherbina. We PUSH IN ON HIM - see the RAGE building inside... cur TO:

Legasov and Tarakanov. Wincing at the sounds of FURNITURE SMASHING and GLASS BREAKING. REVEAL - they're in front of the mobile command trailer. It's ROCKING from within. And now we hear Shcherbina's muffled voice, screaming. INTERCUT BETWEEN - INTERIOR and EXTERIOR of MOBILE OFFICE

The sound of something TOPPLING. Then a STOMPING noise. Legasov lights his cigarette. He looks over and sees: A SOLDIER, standing nearby. Frightened at the noise and ang coming from inside that trailer.

Then the sounds of PLASTIC being battered... the sad clinking of a damaged BELL... and... WHAM. The trailer door gets KICKED OPEN, and Shcherbina emerges, red-faced. He HURLS the smashed remnants of a TELEPHONE into the air the cord trailing behind it... sending it clattering to t ground in pieces. Legasov and Tarakanov wait quietly for Shcherbina to catc his breath. It takes some time. Then:  446 34.

The official position of the State is that a global nuclear catastrophe is not possible in the Soviet Union. (beat) They told the international community the highest detected level of radiation was 2,000 roentgen. Legasov is stunned. Oh god. No.

They gave the propaganda number to the Germans. The robot was never going to work. Tarakanov closes his eyes. Hangs his head. The three men stand there, dejected. Lost. Then Shcherbina, now drained of all his fight, turns to t nearby soldier.
We need a new phone.

CLOSE ON: two glasses. Vodka pours into each. Shcherbina hands a weary Tarakanov one glass. Takes the other for himself. A heavy RAIN batters the tent from outside. Water occasionally drips in through faulty seams
(drinks, then) What if we don't clear it?
We have to clear it. Legasov sits off to the side. Scribbling notations on a p Never looks up. Keeps scribbling as he talks.
If we don't clear the roof, we can't build a cover over it. If we can't build a cover, that's 12,000 roentgen. Nearly twice the radiation from the bomb in Hiroshima, every hour, hour after--  35.
(waves him off) Yes, okay, I remember. (back to Tarakanov) What about lead? We could-- I don't know. We could melt it down, then pour it from above, like a coating.
First of all, we've already used most of the lead we had--
There's lead sheeting around instruments in the other reactor buildings. The soldiers are stripping it to make their armor.
Are you serious? Yes. Shcherbina is serious. Tarakanov shakes his head. Embarrassing. But back to the bigger issue:
Even if, you're still talking about boiling metal in a helicopter-- and it's lead, Boris. It'll weigh a ton... Shcherbina puts his hands up. All right. It was stupid.
What if we shoot the graphite into the hole? Shcherbina looks up from his drink. Excuse me?
We have heavy caliber bullets-- exploding bullets, so they won't just ricochet... they push...
You want to shoot exploding bullets at an exposed nuclear reactor?
(sheepish) Well--  447 36.
No, let's go light the roof back on fire. It was so easy to put out the first time. (frustrated) What are we even talking about? We need another robot. Something that can withstand the radiation.
I've asked. There's nothing.
The Americans--

If the Americans have that kind of technology, do you really think they would give it to us? And even if they would-- the Central Committee will never stoop to ask. You know it, and I know it. (beat) There are no robots.
Biorobots. Shcherbina and Tarakanov turn to Legasov. He's been so quiet, they almost forgot he was there.
What was that? Legasov removes his glasses. Stares down at the calculati on his notepad. Utterly defeated.
We use biorobots. He finally turns to look at them. Grim.
Men. And so, the unthinkable has finally been said.

A cold, gray day. We're in a DEAD FIELD. Plowed earth. Th everpresent RADIATION SIGNS stuck in the ground where scarecrows might have once gone.  448 449 37. IN THE DISTANCE - a small farming village. Barely a dozen tiny homes. GUNSHOTS echo in the air.

PAVEL - walks slowly. Dispassionately. SHOOTING. Aim. Trigger. Fire. Bolt. Shell. Bolt. Aim. Trigger. Fire. It's only been a month, but he looks older somehow. A bit thinner. Sleepless eyes. A numbness. REVEAL - BACHO and GARO walking along side him. Aiming. Firing. The sounds of barking. Yelping. Running. At last, they stop. Animal corpses are scattered along th street in front of them.
A lot today. More than I thought.
(looks around) Where are they getting food? Bacho points between two houses, where a large, ramshackl wooden CHICKEN COOP sits. Dark stains near the opening.
They eat the chickens. (loads more bullets) Then they eat each other. He tosses the stripper clip aside. Chambers a round.
Check the houses.

The barest light streams in through thin drapes. We're looking down a narrow hallway toward the front door. Uneven wooden floors. Cement block walls painted in paste and stained with rust from the rain that's leaked through the tin roof. Almost no furniture. Utter poverty. The door OPENS. Locks are either not needed or not availa in a place like this.  450 38. Pavel enters slowly, eyes adjusting to the light. A door to his right. He quietly pushes it open, wincing a the SQUEAK of the neglected hinges. Peers in. Nothing. He moves down the hall, keeping his footsteps light. Eyes peeled for any movement. Then he hears... a weird little chirpy noise. A bird mayb He MOVES SLOWLY DOWN THE HALL...

LOW ANGLE - a cramped kitchen. Basin with no tap. Rickety shelves nailed to the wall. Torn-open packages of food, broken jars, a spilled bag of flour on the floor... And that weird little chirpy noise again. Louder here. An soft BREATHING. PAVEL - pushes slowly through the swinging door to the kitchen. He looks down. To the right. To the left. And stops. Oh god. PAVEL'S POV - ON THE FLOOR, amidst the garbage... a POODL MUTT BITCH lies on the ground, panting softly and sitting with her LITTER OF SIX PUPPIES... just a few months old.
(yelling from outside) Pavel? Pavel looks dumbstruck at the poodle and her puppies. The bitch stares back at him. Helpless.
We hear FOOTSTEPS from outside, and behind Pavel, we see BACHO enter the kitchen from the back door.
(so there he is) You don't hear me? Pavel doesn't respond. Or turn around. Bacho marches over already enraged.
Hey. I'm talking to--  451 452 453 39. Now Bacho sees the poodle and her litter. He slumps.
Ah fuck. Pavel finally turns to him. It's clear from his face that this is too much. He can't. He can't do it. Bacho nods before Pavel has to say it.
Just go outside. (beat) Go. Pavel wants to stop this. But he can't. This is their job

Pavel emerges. Walks five steps and: GUNSHOT. He stops. Another GUNSHOT. Another. Another. Another. A pause. Pavel takes a small CANTEEN from his belt. Unscr the cap. Takes a drink. Winces. It's not water. GUNSHOT. Pavel steels himself. Canteen back to his mouth. GUNSHOT. Pavel keeps drinking.

POV - through the TRUCK'S WINDSHIELD as it approaches: THE BURIAL PIT - a large hole in the middle of a field, maybe twenty feet wide and six feet deep. Three men stand waiting with shovels. A fourth man is climbing up out of the pit. They've just finished. Behind them, backed up to the edge of the pit, is a CEMENT TRUCK ON BACHO - with Pavel and Garo next to him as always. He slows the truck and turns the wheel...

The STAKEBED has been TILTED UP on its arm, and the last the corpses drop down into the pit.  454 455 456 457 40. Garo and Pavel stand aside from the pit. Not looking in. They've seen it enough times. BACHO - has his hand on the lever controlling the arm. He waits for the last of the corpses to fall, then signals t the men across the pit. The cement truck operator begins the FLOW of CEMENT into pit. It slops down, and we watch as it begins to flow ove the corpses like a blanket.
SCORE - a steady pulse. Adrenaline.
- MILITARY TRUCKS PULL UP - soldiers hop out the back. Double-timing. No smiles. No chatter. Grim business.
Comrade soldiers. - SOLDIERS grab GEAR from a pile. Dingy mustard-yellow boiler suits. Rubber boots. Rubber aprons. Rubber mittens

The Soviet people have had enough of this accident. They want us to clean it up, and we are entrusting you with this serious task. - SOLDIERS suit up. Cowls pulled down over their heads. Boots and gloves. Goggles. Respirators. Faces disappear.
AREA - soldiers in full gear are gathered around Tarakano He paces as he addresses them. 454 455 456 457  41.

Because of the nature of the working area, you will each have no more than ninety seconds to solve this problem. - SOLDIERS help each other don HANDCRAFTED LEAD APRONS, crudely hammered sheets of dark metal. - BRIEFING AREA - TARAKANOV, different day, unshaven, talking to different soldiers.

If you follow instructions and perform your work correctly, you will be fine. There's nothing terrible up there. But safety is our first priority. - BOOTS clomp up the metal stairs that lead to the roof.
You will enter Reactor Building 3. - THE SOLDIERS - covered head to toe, faces obscured behi masks, move slowly up the narrow stairway, their way lit work lights strung along the low ceiling.
Climb the stairs, but do not immediately proceed to the roof. - BRIEFING AREA - NEW SOLDIERS listen to Tarakanov's spee His voice is hoarse. He's done this hundreds of times now
When you get to the top, wait inside behind the entrance to the roof and catch your breath. You will need it for what comes next. He points at photos of the roof that are pinned to the wa

This is the working area. We have to clear the graphite. Some of it is in blocks weighing approximately 40 to 50 kilograms each. It must all be thrown over the side here. - TOP OF THE STAIRS - a dark landing. Soldiers, all weigh down by their lead aprons, catch their breath from the lo climb. BEYOND THEM - looking down a narrow corridor... an OPENING. A rectangle of BRIGHT LIGHT. Waiting.  458 42. - BRIEFING AREA - different day, new soldiers. Tarakanov delivers his speech. Pointing to a BLACK-AND-WHITE TELEVISION, on which plays footage of prior soldiers.
Here. Watch your comrades moving fast from this opening-- - TOP OF THE STAIRS - a masked soldier stares ahead at th bright rectangle of light. Like a portal to another world
--then turning to the left and entering the working area here. - TOP OF THE STAIRS - four soldiers walk slowly toward th rectangle of light, shovels in their hands.

Take care not to stumble. There is a hole in the roof. Take care not to fall. If any part of your skin is exposed, exit the work area at once. - BRIEFING AREA - new day, new soldiers. Tarakanov finish his litany.
Do you understand your mission as I have described it?
Yes, Comrade General.
These are the most important ninety seconds of your lives. Commit your task to memory. Then do your job.

FOUR SOLDIERS are silhouetted against the BRIGHT LIGHT of the opening that leads out to Masha. Shovels in hand. A radiological soldier straps DOSIMETERS to their waists. can already hear steady CLICKING. But he shows no worry. We can't see the faces of the men. But we sense their fea THE SITE OFFICER - holds a stopwatch.  459 43.

It's time to go. After ninety seconds, I will ring a bell. When you hear it, return immediately. Drop your shovels in that bin, and proceed down the hallway for decontamination. (beat) Above all-- while you are on the roof, you will throw the debris over the rail. You will not look over the rail. Is that clear? They nod.
(checks his stopwatch) Very well. On my mark. Ready. Go.

The following unfolds in real time. The shift will last ninety seconds. We will be with them for all ninety secon The men scramble out on to the roof, moving as quickly as they can. One LOSES HIS FOOTING on a piece of graphite. Catches his balance. Keeps going. THE DOSIMETERS - will serve as our SCORE. The clicks increase in frequency and pitch. It sounds like heavy rai on a tin roof now. A soldier PLUNGES his shovel into a pile of BROKEN GRAPHI RUBBLE. Lifts it. Heavier than it looks. He carries his load toward the RAILING... his breathing l in our ears... the dosimeter volume JUMPS in fits and starts... now a constant, heavy STATIC NOISE... We move away from him and find ANOTHER SOLDIER trying to lift a LARGE GRAPHITE BLOCK with his shovel. Too heavy. A second soldier runs over and joins in. They LIFT the block in tandem, and as soon as it rises: The dosimeter SPIKES in volume. They've uncovered a piece FUEL ROD. The terrifying cacophony of a million neutrons firing against their bodies. They don't stop. They waddle in unison toward the railing just as the first soldier hurls his graphite over the edg

We move to find: the FOURTH SOLDIER... striking a hardene patch of BITUMEN and GRAPHITE with the blade of his shove It refuses to give way. He LEANS HIS BODY against the shovel, PUSHES, and then LO HIS GRIP on the shovel handle. It clatters to the surface the roof. He quickly picks it back up. Breathing hard. Fe Another soldier APPEARS. Helps. You're okay. Keep going. They both hammer away at the solidified black tar with th shovels until it finally peels up. The fourth soldier lif it with his shovel. We lead him as he runs to the railing, his boots crunchin on graphite. He gets to the edge and THROWS the shovel-lo over the railing, then SLIPS... ...and catches himself on the railing. Nearly went over. in that split-second, he LOOKS DOWN into: THE OPEN REACTOR PIT. DOSIMETER: a tornado of sound. Deafening. Distorted. He backs off, and now another sound. Distant under the ro of the dosimeter, but growing. Louder now. THE BELL. clang... clang... clang... It's over. Get back. The soldier turns, but: HIS BOOT IS CAUGHT between two pieces of REBAR in CONCRET Behind him, the other soldiers are already running back. Clang... Clang... Clang... Panic. Can't breathe. Dosimeter noise. Boot. Can't take i off. Can't get free. CLANG... CLANG... CLANG... The soldier stabs at the rebar with his shovel blade... i he misses... if he punctures the boot... CLANG... CLANG... CLANG... His boot PULLS FREE. He SPRINTS BACK to the opening as fa as he can, slipping and sliding along the graphite, doesn matter... get off the roof... get off the roof... get off

The soldier returns to the relative safety of the hallway The DOSIMETER noise subsides to a steady, low clicking. A to think that once frightened us. The soldier remembers that he's still holding the shovel. His fingers gripped tight. He flings it into the bin. Then he feels something. PAIN. He looks down at his boot. There's a SMALL RIP in the rubber. He stares at it for a moment, then:
Comrade soldier. The masked soldier looks up. The Site Officer stands ten feet away. Safe distance. He points toward a corridor.

You're done. The soldier hesitates for a moment, as if he's not sure w that even means... ...and then he nods, turns to the corridor that will take him to decontamination, and exits. We never saw his face. We never even knew his name. The Site Officer watches him leave, then turns to: FOUR N SOLDIERS, masked and suited up.
It's time to go.

Children run by, bundled up against the cold, shouting an yelling happily as they play. We're back in the courtyard surrounded by blocky Soviet apartment buildings. LYUDMILLA - heavily pregnant, sits on a bench, still alon Watching the children play. Watching the mothers. And fathers.

462 463 464 46. A RUBBER BALL - bounces across the playground toward Lyudmilla. She bends down with effort to pick it up, anda LITTLE GIRL, 6, runs over to get it. Lyudmilla smiles and hands the ball back to the girl, and the girl smiles back. Then the pain hits. Lyudmilla doubles over. A contraction. The little girl's smile fades. She just stares. WIDE SHOT - from across the courtyard. Women gathered in foreground, chatting. In the B.G., Lyudmilla is doubled over... the little girl standing next to her. The PAIN hits again. Harder. She cries out. The little gi RUNS AWAY, afraid... and finally, one of the grown women turns to see Lyudmilla. Another cry. They all see her now. It's like they're just discovering she exists. And finally, two of the women sta running across the concrete courtyard to help her, and:

Silent streets. The freezing air is still. May Day banner hang limp and torn. Dead trees line the streets. And then, at the far end of the street - MOVEMENT. A Red Army UAZ-469, the Soviet version of a Jeep, turns into vi Slowly moving toward us.
BIRD'S EYE VIEW - the UAZ drives down the street. Nothing else moves in the dead, empty, silent city.

LOW TO THE GROUND - a cluster of dead bramble. The legs o CHILD'S DOLL stick out obscenely from the branches. The UAZ enters, and rolls to a slow stop. KHOMYUK emerges from the passenger side. A FILE FOLDER under her arm.  465 466 47. In front of them, an ugly building. Dull white tiles. Fou stories. Broken windows. She looks around. No one in sigh No sound in the frigid air. They are completely alone. She nods in thanks to the driver and turns to the buildin

Khomyuk walks slowly down a dim corridor. Broken glass occasionally crunching under her feet. Her breath fogging the freezing air. This was an ELEMENTARY SCHOOL. Children artwork shares space on the walls with propaganda posters WATER drips down from the ceiling, plinking into puddles the concrete floor. The barest amount of daylight filters through the small windows in the classroom doors. Khomyuk heads up a staircase to the second floor, and:

Peeling paint. Toppled chairs in a corner. Debris. Cards feature letters of the alphabet ring the walls, intersper with framed pictures of Soviet dignitaries. A fluorescent light half-hangs from the ceiling, suspende by a few remaining wires. SHCHERBINA and LEGASOV - are waiting on the landing.

I'm sorry for all this. But we needed to speak to you without... The KGB listening. She understands. She climbs up the sta to them. All three are bundled up against the cold. Shcherbina looks at Legasov. Tell her.
They're putting Dyatlov on trial. And Bryukhanov. And Fomin. We're going to be called for expert testimony. All three of us. But before that happens-вЂ”
The Central Committee is sending Legasov to Vienna. It's the headquarters of the International--  48.
Atomic Energy Agency, I know what's in Vienna-- (to Legasov) What are they asking you do to?
Tell the world what happened. She feels a quick excitement. And fear. The promise of revealing the truth. And then a flicker of resentment. Because she's done the work. And he'll be the one in Vien
Well then you should know what happened. She opens her file folder. Hands him a report and additio pages as she speaks...
I've constructed a timeline. Minute by minute. Second by second in some places. Every decision. Every button press. Every turn of a switch.
And? Are they guilty? Legasov is flipping pages. Reading. Scanning. Absorbing.

Yes, of gross incompetence, violation of safety regulations, recklessness beyond belief... but the explosion? I'm not sure. And now Legasov closes her report. He's seen enough alrea His worst fear confirmed.
What do you mean you're not sure? She's bored of dealing with Shcherbina. He won't comprehe Not quickly enough at least. She turns back to Legasov.
I've analyzed the data. Toptunov was telling the truth. They shut the reactor down, and then it exploded. She hands him the journal article from her file folder.  49.
I think this article may have the answer. But two pages have been removed. Then she sees on Legasov's face-- foreknowledge. And guil She realizes:
You know what they are. You've seen them before.
Please believe me when I tell you-- I did not know it could lead to an explosion. None of us knew.
(anger rising) None of you knew what. Legasov lifts two toppled chairs into position, then slow sits down. Khomyuk sits in the other.
In 1975 at the RBMK reactor in Leningrad, a fuel channel ruptured. The operators pressed AZ-5, but instead of the power immediately going down, for a brief moment-- it went up.
How is that possible?

That was the very question asked by a colleague of mine named Volkov. He's the one who wrote this article. (to Shcherbina) When the RBMK runs at low power, as it was that night, it's notoriously unstable. Prone to-- swings-- in reactivity. Under normal circumstances, control rods can compensate for that.
Under normal circumstances. (her report) The Chernobyl staff stalled the reactor during the test. They pulled almost all of the control rods to bring the power back up.  50.

This is what Volkov learned from Leningrad. If the boron rods are completely withdrawn from the core, when they're put back in, the first thing into the reactor isn't boron. (beat) It's graphite. The boron control rods have graphite tips that displace water and steam. Reactivity doesn't go down. It goes up. Dramatically. Khomyuk leans back. In shock. But Shcherbina can only sta there dumbly, waiting for an explanation.
Imagine there's a fire in a building. You turn on a hose, but instead of water coming out, it sprays petrol instead.
Then why in god's name did they push that button?
(finally understands) They didn't know. And now Shcherbina takes another chair and sits. My god.. Yes.
Volkov warned the Kremlin ten years ago. But there must be no doubt about the supremacy of the Soviet nuclear industry.
(realizing) The KGB classified it as a state secret.

When I saw the reactor blown open, I still didn't think it could be this flaw in AZ-5... because the flaw will not lead to an explosion unless the operators have first willfully pushed the reactor to the edge of disaster.  51.
So it is their fault.
Yes.
But not only their fault.
No.
And is that what you're going to say? In Vienna? Valery, you have to tell the truth. All of it.
You can't possibly be that naive.

There are 16 RBMK reactors running right now in the Soviet Union. We have to fix them, and the only way to make that happen is to go public. In Vienna, in the West, and force the Central Committee to take action.
What you are proposing is that Legasov humiliate a nation that is obsessed with not being humiliated. Shcherbina swallows his anger. Then, to Legasov:
We can make a deal with the KGB. You leave this information out in Vienna, and they quietly allow us to fix the remaining reactors.
A deal. With the KGB. And I'm naive... Legasov doesn't know how to respond. Caught between the t of them. Between his heart and his mind.
Valery, they will go after your friends, your family--  52.
You have a chance to talk to the world. If it were me--

But it isn't, is it. I have been a part of this system for 44 years, so listen carefully. I have known braver souls than you, Khomyuk. Men who had their moment and did nothing, because when it is your life and the lives of everyone you love, your moral conviction doesn't mean a damn thing. It leaves you. And all you want in that moment is not to be shot. A few seconds. Then she turns calmly to Legasov.
Do you know the name Vasily Ignatenko? Legasov shakes his head no.

He was a fireman. He died two weeks after the accident. I've been looking in on his widow. She gave birth today. A girl. (beat) The baby lived four hours. She had 28 roentgen. They said the radiation would have killed the mother, but the baby absorbed it instead. Her baby. (quietly) We live in a country where children have to die to save their mothers. The hell with our names and the hell with your deals. Someone has to start telling the truth. Legasov looks at them. Khomyuk, who is right. And Shcherbina... who is also right. And only he can decide.
Congratulations, comrades.
Completely clean of debris. Two men emerge onto the roof. One carries a metal POLE. The other has a cylindrical cas strapped to his back.  468 469 470 53.
You are the last of 3,828 men.
Tarakanov addresses a group of eight soldiers, still in their heavy gear, but not wearing gloves or masks.
You have performed your duties perfectly. I wish you good health and long life. All of you are awarded with a bonus of 800 rubles. Tarakanov approaches the first soldier. Shakes his hand.
Thank you.
I serve the Soviet Union. Tarakanov moves to the second soldier. Shakes his hand.
Thank you.
I serve the Soviet Union.

location: VERY TOP OF THE COOLING TOWER

text: The two men attach a pole and RED FLAG to the top of the tower. It flaps in the wind.
Thank you.
I serve the Soviet Union.

From here, we can see the REACTOR SITE in the near distan And the RED FLAG fluttering on the cooling tower. PAVEL - stands in place, gazing out at it. He's gaunt. Sallow skin. His hair seems thinner. Numb. Blank stare. He's smoking now.  471 54. A YOUNG RECRUIT, 21, fresh-faced believer, walks up to Pavel, and joins him looking out at the flag.
Makes you proud, doesn't it, comrade? Pavel doesn't look at him. Just keeps staring out.

They sent me over to you. For assignment. (his radiation badge) They gave me this to wear. I guess everyone has one. We don't have anything to worry about, right? Pavel still doesn't look at him. But:
You can get up to 24 roentgen before there's a problem.
Oh. How much do you have? Pavel keeps his eyes locked on the flag. Takes a long dra on his cigarette. Then:

The maternity ward. New mothers pass in front of us. Some walking, some being wheeled. Cradling their newborns. But we move through them like we're not there. Like we're ghost. Until we find an open door... and stop. In a bare room, LYUDMILLA sits on the edge of the bed, st in a hospital gown, looking out the window. Forgotten. An alone.
